case_vignette: A 25-year-old man comes to the physician because of right-sided painless scrotal swelling that he noticed yesterday while taking a shower. He is currently sexually active with two female partners and uses condoms inconsistently. He immigrated to the US from Argentina 2 years ago. His immunization records are unavailable. He has smoked one pack of cigarettes daily for the last 5 years. He is 170 cm (5 ft 7 in) tall and weighs 70 kg (154 lb); BMI is 24.2 kg/m2. He appears healthy and well nourished. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 72/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mm Hg. The lungs are clear to auscultation. Cardiac examination shows no abnormalities. The abdomen is soft with dull lower abdominal discomfort. Testicular examination shows a solid mass in the right testis that is firm and nontender. A light held behind the scrotum does not shine through. The mass is not reduced when the patient is in a supine position. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Renal and Genitourinary System. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I noticed a painless swelling on the right side of my scrotum yesterday.
When did you first notice the swelling and has its size changed since then?
I first noticed the swelling yesterday, and the size has not changed since I noticed it.
Have you experienced any other symptoms such as fever, nausea, or changes in urination?
No, I haven't had any fever, nausea, or changes in urination.
Do you have a history of trauma or injury to the scrotal area?
No, I have not had any trauma or injury to the scrotal area.
Is the swollen area on the scrotum tender to touch or red?
The swollen area is firm and not tender, and there's no mention of redness.
Do you have a history of infections or surgeries in the genitourinary tract?
No, I don't have a history of infections or surgeries in the genitourinary tract.
Does the swelling change in size when you lay down or apply pressure to it?
The swelling does not change in size when I lay down or apply pressure to it.
Have you noticed any change in the consistency or feel of your testicle on the side with the swelling?
Yes, there's a solid mass in the right testis that feels firm.
Do you have a family history of cancer, particularly testicular cancer?
I don't know, I am not aware of my family's medical history.
Have you ever had a similar swelling in the past?
No, I've never had a similar swelling in the past.
Have you experienced any recent unintended weight loss or night sweats?
No, I haven't experienced any unintended weight loss or night sweats.
Are you currently experiencing any difficulty with ejaculation or erection?
No, I'm not having any difficulty with ejaculation or erection.

Based on the symptoms described, a painless firm mass within the testicle that does not change with position or pressure, the most likely diagnosis is:

**Final Diagnosis:**
Testicular cancer.
